abstract_summ: The aim of this paper is to examine in detail the potential impact on SARS-CoV-2 infection of treatments routinely used in trichology and to provide a useful guide for the therapeutic management of thricological patients in this new COVID-19 era.SARS‐CoV‐2 is mostly transmitted through respiratory droplets and contact routes, but the WHO also states that “airborne transmission may be possible in specific circumstances and settings in which procedures or support treatments that generate aerosols are performed” (WHO, 2020).As COVID-19 spreads through the world, most cases to date are in middle- and high-income nations.The objective of this report is to provide cytopathology professionals a timely, in‐depth, evidence‐based review of biosafety practices for those at risk for coronavirus (COVID‐19) infection.This commentary focuses on the cytopathology laboratory, the authors' experiences with coronavirus (COVID‐19) in Taiwan, and current guidelines on COVID‐19 infection prevention and control.The coronavirus disease of 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic has created new challenges and magnified existing ones for immunocompromised individuals who may be at risk for worse clinical outcomes.
title_summ: Characterization of 100 sequential SARS-CoV-2 convalescent plasma donationsBiosafety in the preparation and processing of cytology specimens with potential coronavirus (COVID‐19) infection: Perspectives from TaiwanHand disinfection in the combat against Covid‐19Is 0.5% Hydrogen Peroxide Effective against SARS‐CoV‐2?Will helminth co-infection modulate COVID-19 severity in endemic regions?When COVID-19 Crosses Paths with AIDS in the Homeless.Recommendations on trichological treatments during COVID-19 pandemic.
title_abstract_phrases: Is 0.5% Hydrogen Peroxide Effective against SARS‐CoV‐2?SARS‐CoV‐2 is mostly transmitted through respiratory droplets and contact routes, but the WHO also states that “airborne transmission may be possible in specific circumstances and settings in which procedures or support treatments that generate aerosols are performed” (WHO, 2020).Will helminth co-infection modulate COVID-19 severity in endemic regions?As COVID-19 spreads through the world, most cases to date are in middle- and high-income nations.The aim of this paper is to examine in detail the potential impact on SARS-CoV-2 infection of treatments routinely used in trichology and to provide a useful guide for the therapeutic management of thricological patients in this new COVID-19 era.Recommendations on trichological treatments during COVID-19 pandemic.Here, we discuss whether the immunomodulatory effects of helminth infections may affect COVID-19 severity.When COVID-19 Crosses Paths with AIDS in the Homeless.
